AQI (Air Quality Index) is a standardized indicator that measures how polluted the air is. It ranges from 0 to 500:

ğŸŸ¢ 0-50: Good
ğŸŸ¡ 51-100: Satisfactory
ğŸŸ  101-200: Moderate
ğŸ”´ 201-300: Poor
ğŸŸ£ 301-400: Very Poor
ğŸŸ¤ 401-500: Severe

Lower values mean cleaner, healthier air!

PM2.5 refers to fine particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 micrometers or smaller (about 3% the diameter of a human hair!). ğŸ”¬

These tiny particles can:
â€¢ Penetrate deep into lungs
â€¢ Enter the bloodstream
â€¢ Cause respiratory problems
â€¢ Aggravate heart disease
â€¢ Reduce life expectancy

âœ… Safe level: 0-30 Âµg/mÂ³
âš ï¸ Unhealthy: Above 60 Âµg/mÂ³

PM10 refers to coarse particulate matter with a diameter of 10 micrometers or smaller. These particles include:

â€¢ Dust
â€¢ Pollen
â€¢ Mold spores
â€¢ Combustion particles

PM10 can irritate the eyes, nose, and throat, but is less dangerous than PM2.5 since it doesn't penetrate as deeply into the lungs.

âœ… Safe level: 0-50 Âµg/mÂ³

responses:
Ways to reduce pollution exposure:

ğŸ  Indoors:
â€¢ Use air purifiers with HEPA filters
â€¢ Keep windows closed on high pollution days
â€¢ Ventilate during early morning (6-8 AM)
â€¢ Add indoor plants (but don't rely on them alone)

ğŸš¶ Outdoors:
â€¢ Wear N95/N99 masks
â€¢ Avoid peak traffic hours (8-11 AM, 5-9 PM)
â€¢ Choose less-trafficked routes
â€¢ Exercise early morning or late evening
â€¢ Stay away from construction sites

ğŸš— Commuting:
â€¢ Use public transport
â€¢ Keep car windows closed
â€¢ Use cabin air filters
â€¢ Avoid idling in traffic

ğŸ’ª Health:
â€¢ Stay hydrated
â€¢ Eat antioxidant-rich foods
â€¢ Regular health check-ups

People most sensitive to air pollution:

ğŸ‘¶ Children
â€¢ Lungs still developing
â€¢ Breathe more air per body weight
â€¢ More active outdoors

ğŸ‘´ Elderly (65+)
â€¢ Weakened immune systems
â€¢ Often have pre-existing conditions

ğŸ« People with Respiratory Conditions
â€¢ Asthma
â€¢ COPD
â€¢ Bronchitis

â¤ï¸ Heart Disease Patients
â€¢ Pollution can trigger heart attacks
â€¢ Aggravates existing conditions

ğŸ¤° Pregnant Women
â€¢ Risk to fetal development
â€¢ Can affect birth weight

ğŸ’ª Athletes & Outdoor Workers
â€¢ Higher breathing rates
â€¢ More exposure

These groups should take extra precautions during high pollution days!

patterns: Best time of year for air quality

responses:
Seasonal pollution patterns in Bengaluru:

ğŸ¥¶ Winter (Nov-Feb): WORST
â€¢ Temperature inversion traps pollutants
â€¢ Low wind speeds
â€¢ Crop burning in nearby states
â€¢ Diwali firecrackers (Oct-Nov)

â˜€ï¸ Summer (Mar-May): MODERATE
â€¢ Higher temperatures aid dispersion
â€¢ But dust storms increase PM10
â€¢ Construction activity peaks

ğŸŒ§ï¸ Monsoon (Jun-Sep): BEST
â€¢ Rain washes out pollutants
â€¢ Cleaner air
â€¢ Less dust

ğŸ‚ Post-Monsoon (Oct): MODERATE
â€¢ Transition period
â€¢ Festival season begins
â€¢ Air quality starts deteriorating

Best time for outdoor activities: During and after monsoon (June-October)!

NO2 (Nitrogen Dioxide) is a reddish-brown gas formed by:

âš¡ Power plants

Health Effects:
â€¢ Irritates airways

CO (Carbon Monoxide) is a colorless, odorless gas produced by incomplete combustion:

ğŸš— Vehicle emissions (primary source)
ğŸ­ Industrial processes
ğŸ”¥ Biomass burning

Health Effects:
â€¢ Reduces oxygen delivery to organs
â€¢ Causes headaches, dizziness
â€¢ Impairs vision and coordination
â€¢ Fatal at high concentrations

âœ… Safe level: <2 mg/mÂ³ (8-hour avg)
âš ï¸ Dangerous: >10 mg/mÂ³

Ozone (O3) at ground level is a harmful pollutant (though beneficial in the upper atmosphere!).

How it forms:
â˜€ï¸ Sunlight + NOx + VOCs â†’ Ozone

Highest during sunny afternoons!

Air Purifier Guide:

âœ… Do They Work?
Yes! HEPA filters can remove 99.97% of PM2.5 particles.

ğŸ” What to Look For:
â€¢ True HEPA filter (H13 or H14)

ğŸ“ Where to Place:
â€¢ Bedroom (spend 8+ hours)
â€¢ Living room

ğŸ”§ Maintenance:
